item.title: By: Elly Foster
item.dc:creator: Elly Foster
item.description:
Hi Michael
I read some research in the BBC Wildlife magazine a few months ago where the relationship between testicle size and male parental duties was described. If I remember correctly, it was in a species of bird. Biologists and psychologists often carry out, to us, rather bizarre experiments.
Have you heard the latest Billy Bragg song? I think you'll like it. It's about the image of a man as the person who does diy in the house, or not, as the case may be. Billy Bragg prefers to see himself as a poet.
Elly

item.title: By: Anne Lawlor
item.dc:creator: Anne Lawlor
item.description: Oh wonders of wonders.... an intelligent, well thought out MALE voice. Of course the world would be a better and far more balanced place to live in if men were less 'macho' and more involved with kids. The world doesn't need supermen, what it needs is 'ordinary heroes'. And you're right, it does take "balls to be a bit different: particularly if you are a man who is prepared to look after his children in a society, culture or area where this may be judged to be unusual." In this woman's book this is my definition of REAL balls. Bring on the male revolution I say. Anne Anne

item.title: By: Julie Barton
item.dc:creator: Julie Barton
item.content:encoded:
In the US, only 3-5% of the early childhood workforce is male. I recently graduated from the early childhood program at a state university in New York. Only 2 men were enrolled in the program. (Three actually started; however, an early childhood professor convinced one of them to change his major.)

I just read an article in the May 2010, National Association for the Education of Young Children’s journal “Young Children.” The title of the article was “Men in Your Teacher Preparation Program: Five Strategies to Recruit and Retain Them.” Those five strategies were:

(1)Have men work with children immediately;
(2)Provide a mentor;
(3)Facilitate a men’s support group;
(4)Offer men a scholarship or stipend; and
(5)Adapt the program’s culture to welcome men

I think that these strategies could also be applied successfully in the workplace.

Too many young children in the US lack a positive male role model in their lives. It would be wonderful if we could convince more men to become early childhood teachers!
